awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Internal Control Design for a Portable Cholera Pathogen Detector
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is an inexpensive handheld smartphone device for rapid detection of pathogens, such as cholera, in environmental water sources. Current water-based pathogen detection methods involve a 3-5 day laboratory procedure. Our alternative is a portable smartphone-enabled platform working offline to detect the pathogen in under 30 minutes . When the smartphone has connectivity, geo-mapped and time-stamped detection results are sent to relevant stakeholders. This novel and proactive approach for detection can enable organizations to remediate water sources prior to community infection. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project addresses the need to develop a rapid and portable field-ready DNA amplification device for pathogen detection. The Phase II project integrates a polyethylene glycol linker as an internal amplification control for device verification and validation. This project proposes a new assay design integrating a polyethylene glycol linker to eliminate extra user steps, while maintaining assay sensitivity and specificity.   The project's technical objectives include systems engineering of an internal amplification control into the hardware functionality of the device. This project will advance the development of a fully integrated sample-to-answer device for detection of waterborne pathogens.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Current cholera detection platforms are time-intensive, costly, and imprecise, exacerbating wide-scale disease outbreaks throughout the world. This disease causes approximately 3 million cases across the globe each year and wastes $2 billion annually in treatments and lost productivity that could be avoided through early detection. OmniVis’ hardware device and consumable test kit (razor/razor blade model) solution reduce the detection process from 3-5 days down to 40 minutes, more accurately and affordably than other solutions on the market. Additionally, OmniVis’ data gathering & reporting tools provide insight over disease hotspots, enabling earlier warning before wide-scale outbreaks occur. OmniVis will leverage weaknesses in the existing water testing market.

 

In this NSF SBIR Phase II grant, OmniVis completed 3 main objectives to push their technology toward commercialization, building off of their development from the NSF SBIR Phase I. The OmniVis technology combines a molecular assay based on isothermal DNA amplification, and analyzing the movement of fluorescent particles. Therefore, our first objective was to develop a unique polyethylene glycol spacer that could bind the DNA from our isothermal assay to our fluorescent particles, while minimizing steric hindrance and maximizing our reaction yield. This objective was successfully completed and we were able to design the space and integrate it into our system. Completion of objective 1 allows us to have an assay that is competitive for field use. 


For our second objective, we designed and characterized an internal amplification (IAC) control for our assays. An IAC allows the OmniVis test to determine that there are no false negatives. By the end of Objective 2, we successfully designed an IAC that we could implement into the OmniVis test kits.

 

For Objective 3, we successfully redesigned the OmniVis device and single-use disposable test kits to integrate the new polyethylene glycol spacer (from Objective 1) and the IAC (from Objective 2). This included making a 3-well test kit that integrated a sample, IAC, and negative control, and having the hardware individually image and analyze the output of all 3 wells of the test kit.

 

By the end of the NSF SBIR Phase II grant, we had a device that allowed for sample-to-answer analysis of the bacteria causing cholera from environmental water samples. Our design can be used for field testing cholera as well as for other bacteria, virus, and parasites, showing its ubiquity in many different testing markets.


Last Modified: 07/07/2023
Modified by: Katherine N Clayton
